choices.text: Closure of aortic and pulmonary valves
Vibrations in the ventricular wall during systole
Closure of mitral and tricuspid valves

questions.text: The fourth heart sound is caused by: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ventricular filling

 

The fourth heart sound is caused by ventricular filling.

 

  • Atrial Heart Sound (Fourth Heart Sound) – Occurs when the atria contract, and presumably, it is caused by the inrush of blood into the ventricles, which initiates vibrations similar to those of the third heart sound.

 

Other heart sounds:

 

  • First heart sound – contraction of the ventricles first causes sudden backflow of blood against the A-V valves (the tricuspid and mitral valves) causing them to close producing the first heart sound.
  • The second heart sound results from sudden closure of the semilunar valves at the end of systole.
  • Third Heart Sound – occasionally a weak, rumbling third heart sound is heard at the beginning of the middle third of diastole. Most probably it is due to oscillation of blood back and forth between the walls of the ventricles initiated by inrushing blood from the atria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fourth heart sound (S4) is caused by the atrial contraction and the subsequent inrush of blood into the ventricles, which initiates vibrations similar to those of the third heart sound.

choices.text: Both surface tension and compliance decreased
Both surface tension and compliance increased

questions.text: A preterm baby who was delivered at 28 weeks developed respiratory distress syndrome. Which of the following is true about surface tension and compliance in this baby?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Surface tension - increased; Compliance - decreased

 

Explanation

 

This preterm baby who developed respiratory distress syndrome has surfactant deficiency. Due to which surface tension increases and compliance decreases.

 

Surfactant (Lecithin/Dipalmitoyl phosphatidyl Choline) is produced by specialized cells called type II alveolar cells in the lungs. Surfactant molecules have a hydrophilic (water-attracting) head and a hydrophobic (water-repellent) tail. This unique structure allows surfactant to lower the surface tension at the air-liquid interface of the alveoli. It reduces the attractive forces between water molecules, preventing the alveoli from collapsing during expiration.

 

Compliance refers to the ability of the lungs to expand and recoil efficiently during breathing. Without surfactant, the surface tension within the alveoli would be high, making it difficult for the lungs to inflate during inspiration and causing them to collapse more readily during expiration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In preterm infants, especially those born before the lungs have matured at around 28 weeks, the lack of adequate surfactant leads to increased surface tension and decreased compliance, contributing to the development of respiratory distress syndrome.

choices.text: A - Cortisol B - Aldosterone C - Androgens D - Epinephrine
A - Aldosterone B - Cortisol C - Androgens D - Epinephrine
A - Epinephrine B - Cortisol C - Aldosterone D - Androgens
A - Aldosterone B - Epinephrine C - Androgens D - Cortisol

questions.text: Which hormones are produced from these zones? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A - Aldosterone B - Cortisol C - Androgens D - Epinephrine

 

Explanation:

 

The adrenal gland, located on top of the kidneys, consists of the adrenal cortex and the adrenal medulla. The cortex is further divided into three zones: the zona glomerulosa, zona fasciculata, and zona reticularis. These zones are responsible for producing different types of hormones, remembered by the mnemonic "GFR."

 

  • Zona Glomerulosa (A): This outermost layer is responsible for producing mineralocorticoids, the most important being Aldosterone. Aldosterone plays a critical role in regulating sodium and potassium balance in the body.
  • Zona Fasciculata (B): The middle layer produces glucocorticoids, primarily Cortisol. Cortisol is involved in stress response, metabolism regulation, and immune function.
  • Zona Reticularis (C): The innermost cortical layer produces androgens, specifically DHEA (Dehydroepiandrosterone), which is a precursor to sex steroids like testosterone and estrogen.
  • Adrenal Medulla (D): The medulla produces catecholamines, primarily Epinephrine (adrenaline), which is crucial for the fight-or-flight response.

 

Educational Objective:


The adrenal cortex is divided into three zones—zona glomerulosa, zona fasciculata, and zona reticularis—which produce aldosterone, cortisol, and androgens, respectively. The adrenal medulla produces catecholamines, primarily epinephrine

choices.text: Decrease in GFR
Decreases renal blood flow
Decreases oncotic pressure in glomerular capillaries
Increases hydrostatic pressure in glomerular capillaries

questions.text: Efferent arteriolar constriction causes all except? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decreases oncotic pressure in glomerular capillaries

 

Explanation

 

 

Efferent arteriolar constriction increases oncotic pressure in glomerular capillaries.

 

Constriction of the efferent arterioles:

 

  1. Increases the resistance to outflow from the glomerular capillaries raising the glomerular hydrostatic pressure
  2. Reduces renal blood flow
  3. Increase in filtration fraction and glomerular colloid osmotic pressure (oncotic pressure)

 

Therefore, if the constriction of efferent arterioles is severe (more than about a threefold increase in efferent arteriolar resistance), the rise in colloid osmotic pressure (oncotic pressure) exceeds the increase in glomerular capillary hydrostatic pressure caused by efferent arteriolar constriction. When this occurs, the net force for filtration actually decreases, causing a reduction in GFR.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decrease in GFR: Incorrect in this context as initial efferent arteriolar constriction might actually increase GFR by raising hydrostatic pressure, though severe constriction can eventually decrease it.

 

Option B. Decreases renal blood flow: Incorrect as this is a direct effect of efferent arteriolar constriction.

 

Option D. Increases hydrostatic pressure in glomerular capillaries: Incorrect as this is indeed a result of efferent arteriolar constriction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Efferent arteriolar constriction leads to an increase in both hydrostatic and oncotic pressures within the glomerular capillaries, which can modify renal blood flow and the dynamics of glomerular filtration. It does not decrease the oncotic pressure in the glomerular capillaries.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man with a history of dyslipidemia, hypertension, and aortic sclerosis presents to the emergency department with chest pain. He took 3 NTG tablets with no relief. His vitals are stable and cardiac enzymes were normal. An ECG on admission is shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Unstable Angina

 

The patient's presentation includes chest pain unrelieved by nitroglycerin (NTG), stable vitals, and normal cardiac enzymes. The provided ECG is normal, showing no signs of ST elevation or ischemic changes such as ST depression or T wave inversion.

 

Unstable Angina involves chest pain at rest or with minimal exertion, and normal cardiac enzymes. The patient has multiple risk factors (dyslipidemia, hypertension, aortic sclerosis), and the fact that his chest pain did not respond to NTG and his enzymes are normal strongly suggests unstable angina.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. STEMI: STEMI is characterized by ST elevation on ECG and elevated cardiac enzymes indicating myocardial necrosis. This patient's ECG shows no ST elevation, and his cardiac enzymes are normal, making STEMI unlikely.

 

Option B. NSTEMI: NSTEMI would present with elevated cardiac enzymes due to myocardial damage, despite the absence of ST elevation. This patient’s normal enzyme levels exclude NSTEMI.

 

Option C. Stable Angina: Stable angina presents with chest pain that is typically relieved by rest or nitroglycerin. The patient’s chest pain persisted despite taking NTG, indicating that stable angina is not the correct diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Unstable angina is characterized by chest pain that occurs at rest or with minimal exertion, does not respond to nitroglycerin, and is associated with normal cardiac enzyme levels.

questions.text:
Organize the listed bands within the sarcomere, starting from the periphery and moving towards the center. (INICET MAY 2023)

 

 

  1. Z line
  2. M line
  3. A band
  4. H zone
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1,3,4,2

 

The proper order of bands within the sarcomere, moving from the periphery towards the center, is as follows: Z line - I band - A band - H zone - M line.

 

 

Z line: A dense protein structure that separates one sarcomere from the next and serves as an anchor for actin filaments.

 

I band: The light-colored region in a sarcomere composed of only thin actin filaments.

 

A band: The dark-colored region in a sarcomere containing both thick myosin and thin actin filaments.

 

H zone: The central part of the A band where only thick myosin filaments are present.

 

M line: The center of the sarcomere, providing structural support and anchoring the myosin filaments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of bands within the sarcomere, from the periphery towards the center, is Z line, A band, H zone, and M line.

choices.text: Primary active transport
Secondary active transport
Any of the above

questions.text: The mechanism by which glucose is absorbed in the intestine is? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Secondary active transport

 

  1. Glucose enters the lumen of the small intestine.
  2. Sodium ions (Na+) are present in the lumen of the intestine.
  3. Sodium-Glucose Co-Transporter 1 (SGLT1) on the luminal membrane of enterocytes facilitates glucose absorption:
    1. SGLT1 binds to both glucose and sodium ions.
    2. Sodium ions move down their electrochemical gradient into the enterocyte, providing energy for transport.
    3. Glucose molecules are co-transported with sodium ions into the enterocyte.
  4. Glucose enters the cytoplasm of the enterocyte.
  5. Inside the enterocyte, glucose can be used for energy or transported across the basolateral membrane.
  6. Glucose Transporter 2 (GLUT2) on the basolateral membrane of enterocytes facilitates glucose transport out of the cell:
    1. GLUT2 allows glucose to move down its concentration gradient.
    2. Glucose diffuses across the basolateral membrane into the bloodstream.
  7. Glucose is carried away by the bloodstream to various tissues and organs for utilization.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary active transport: Involves direct use of ATP for the movement of substances against their concentration gradient and does not apply to glucose absorption in the intestine.

 

Option C. Facilitated diffusion: Passive movement of molecules along their concentration gradient through a membrane protein, applies to the exit of glucose at the basolateral side but not to its uptake at the luminal side.

 

Option D. Any of the above: Not applicable as the specific mechanism for glucose absorption is secondary active transport.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucose is absorbed in the intestine through secondary active transport utilizing the Sodium-Glucose Co-Transporter 1 (SGLT1), which couples the energetically favorable transport of sodium with the transport of glucose against its gradient into enterocytes.

questions.text: The graph given below shows the normal FEV1 and FVC curves for a normal lung and a diseased lung. The abnormal graph represents which of the following?(INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) COPD

 

In the provided spirometry graph, the normal and abnormal curves represent volumes and flow rates during forced expiration.

 

The abnormal graph is indicative of COPD, as it shows a significant reduction in FEV1 with a less pronounced reduction in FVC, resulting in a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio

 

Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) is characterized by a decrease in FEV1 with a more preserved FVC, leading to a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio, which is consistent with the abnormal curve in the graph.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchiectasis: This condition where the walls of airways (bronchi) widen and are thickened from inflammation. It can cause obstructive lung changes, but the FEV1/FVC ratio is often normal or less dramatically reduced than in COPD. The spirometry curve will not show the same pattern as shown in graph.

 

Option B. Sarcoidosis: This is a restrictive lung disease, typically showing a reduction in both FEV1 and FVC but with a normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio, unlike the pattern shown for the diseased lung in the graph.

 

Option C. Pulmonary fibrosis: As a restrictive disease, pulmonary fibrosis would typically show a decrease in lung volumes (including FVC) with a normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio, which differs from the obstructive pattern shown.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The spirometry pattern for COPD shows a significant reduction in FEV1 with a less pronounced reduction in FVC, leading to a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio. This is indicative of obstructive lung disease.

questions.text: Calculate the respiratory quotient (RQ) in a patient with 50kg body weight, if the CO2 exhaled is 200ml/min and 02 consumed is 250 ml/min? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 0.8

 

The respiratory quotient is 0.8.

 

This ratio of carbon dioxide output to oxygen usage is called the respiratory quotient. In the above problem, the CO2 production is 200mL/min, while the 02 consumption is 250mL/min.


So, Respiratory quotient = 200/250 = 0.8

 

Educational Objective:

 

The respiratory quotient (RQ) is used for determining the metabolic utilization of various foods.

 

  • RQ of carbohydrates is 1
  • RQ of fats is 0.70.
  • RQ of proteins is 0.80.

questions.text: Which Reflex is responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Bainbridge reflex

 

Explanation

 

Bainbridge reflex is a cardioaccelerator reflex that increases the heart rate when venous return is increased. Since this reflex arises from right atrium, it is also called right atrial reflex.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. J Reflex: Apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension due to J receptor (C-receptor, juxta-pulmonary capillary receptor) stimulation.

 

Option B. Cushing Reflex: Incorrect because the Cushing reflex involves increased blood pressure, bradycardia, and respiratory depression in response to increased intracranial pressure, not right atrial distension.

 

Option C. Bezold-Jarisch Reflex: Bezold-Jarisch reflex is the reflex characterized by bradycardia and hypotension, caused by stimulation of chemoreceptors present in the wall of left ventricles by substances such as alkaloids. It is also called coronary chemoreflex. Vagal fibers form the afferent and efferent pathways of this reflex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bainbridge reflex is responsible for inducing tachycardia in response to right atrial distension. It serves to adjust heart rate upward when venous return to the heart increases, ensuring optimal cardiac output and circulation efficiency.

choices.text: Active Na+ reabsorption, passive CI- reabsorption, passive K+ secretion, active secretion of HCO3-
Passive Na+ reabsorption, active CI- reabsorption, passive K+ secretion, active secretion of HCO3-
Passive Na+ secretion, active CI- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-
Active Na+ reabsorption, passive CI- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-

questions.text: The second phase of saliva secretion involves: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Active Na+ reabsorption, passive CI- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-

 

First, sodium ions are actively reabsorbed from all the salivary ducts and potassium ions are actively secreted in exchange for the sodium. Excess sodium reabsorption over potassium secretion, creates electrical negativity of about -70 millivolts in the salivary ducts; this in turn causes chloride ions to be reabsorbed passively. Therefore, the chloride ion concentration in the salivary fluid falls to a very low level, matching the ductal decrease in sodium ion concentration.

 

Active Na+ reabsorption

 

(The ductal cells actively transport sodium ions (Na+) from the saliva into the interstitial fluid surrounding the ducts. This reabsorption of sodium ions helps in concentrating the saliva). Conc.  15 mEq/L

              ↓

Passive Cl- reabsorption

(As sodium ions are reabsorbed, chloride ions (Cl-) passively follow along due to electrical charge balance. This results in the reabsorption of chloride ions from the saliva into the interstitial fluid). Conc.  15 mEq/L

              ↓

Active K+ secretion

(The ductal cells actively secrete potassium ions (K+) into the saliva. This secretion helps in maintaining the concentration of potassium ions within the saliva). Conc.  30 mEq/L

              ↓

Passive secretion of HCO3-

(Hydrogen carbonate ions (HCO3-) are passively secreted from the ductal cells into the saliva. This helps in maintaining the alkaline nature of saliva, which aids in buffering acidic substances and maintaining oral pH). Conc. 50 to 70 mEq/L,

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Active Na+ reabsorption, passive Cl- reabsorption, passive K+ secretion, active secretion of HCO3-: Incorrect. While Na+ and Cl- processes are correct, K+ secretion is active, not passive.

 

Option B. Passive Na+ reabsorption, active Cl- reabsorption, passive K+ secretion, active secretion of HCO3-: Incorrect. Na+ reabsorption and Cl- reabsorption roles are reversed, and K+ secretion is active.

 

Option C. Passive Na+ secretion, active Cl- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-: Incorrect. Na+ reabsorption should be active, not passive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The second phase of saliva secretion involves active Na+ reabsorption, passive Cl- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, and passive secretion of HCO3-, crucial for maintaining electrolyte balance and pH in saliva.

choices.text: Central capillary dilatation → Wheal → Surrounding flare.
Central capillary dilatation → Wheal without surrounding flare.
Central capillary dilatation → Wheal with exaggerated surrounding flare.

questions.text: On performing a Histamine test on an individual with brachial plexus trunk injury, you can expect? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Central capillary dilatation → Wheal without surrounding flare

 

In patient with brachial plexus trunk injury, there is anesthesia over the skin in that region. Histamine test in this patient will result in capillary dilatation and wheal without surrounding flare.

 

Intradermal injection of histamine usually causes a triple response in the surrounding skin which includes a red reaction, flare and wheal.

 

  • Red reaction is because of capillary dilatation and is independent of innervation.
  • Flare reaction is due to dilatation of arterioles caused by the axon reflex.
  • Axon reflex or antidromic reflex is the process by which the impulses are conducted in a direction opposite to the normal direction. Normally, the impulses produced by a cutaneous pain receptor pass through sensory nerve fiber towards the nerve cell body in posterior nerve root ganglion. Some of these impulses pass through the other branches of the same fiber in the opposite direction and reach the blood vessels supplied by these branches. Impulses now dilate the blood vessels. This is called the antidromic or axon reflex. Thus, flare is absent in anesthetized skin.
  • Wheal (skin edema) is due to increased capillary permeability

 

The triple response can be seen after total sympathectomy

 

The incomplete triple response over the anesthetic skin is characteristic of postganglionic lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with a brachial plexus trunk injury, the histamine test will result in central capillary dilatation and a wheal without the surrounding flare due to the disruption of the axon reflex.

questions.text: Transport of iron into enterocytes is done by which of the following proteins: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Divalent metal transporter – 1

 

Transport of iron into enterocytes is done by divalent metal transporter-1 protein.

Iron absorption occurs in the duodenum. Iron is reduced to Fe2+ (ferrous) iron by ferrireductases and then transported across the apical membrane by divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transferrin: This protein binds iron in the bloodstream and transports it to various tissues, but it is not involved in the transport of iron into enterocytes.

 

Option B. Ferroportin: This protein exports iron from enterocytes into the bloodstream but does not transport iron into the cells.

 

Option C. Hepcidin: This hormone regulates iron egress from enterocytes by inhibiting ferroportin but is not involved in the transport of iron into enterocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary transporter responsible for iron uptake into enterocytes from the intestinal lumen is the divalent metal transporter-1 (DMT1).

questions.text: In fetal circulation, which vessel carries deoxygenated blood back to the placenta? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Umbilical artery

 

The umbilical arteries are responsible for transporting deoxygenated blood from the fetal heart to the placenta during gestation. In general, arteries carry oxygenated blood away from the heart, but the pulmonary and umbilical arteries are unique in that they carry deoxygenated blood.

 

 

Clinical significance:

 

  1. The medial umbilical ligament is the remnant of the umbilical artery. The umbilical artery has the following fate:
    • Proximal parts persist as the superior vesical arteries
    • Distal parts get obliterated and form the medial umbilical ligaments
  2. The normal umbilical cord contains 2 arteries and 1 vein. A single umbilical artery is the most common cord abnormality. The incidence is higher in twin deliveries. Thus, identifying this during the head-to-toe examination of the newborn becomes extremely important. Congenital anomalies are seen in 30% of cases with a single umbilical artery, trisomy 18 is a common association.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Umbilical Vein: The umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus.

 

Option C. Descending Aorta: In fetal circulation, the descending aorta distributes oxygenated blood from the heart to the lower parts of the body and is not specifically involved in the transport of deoxygenated blood to the placenta.

 

Option D. Pulmonary Artery: The pulmonary artery carries deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle to the lungs in postnatal circulation but does not play a role in fetal circulation in terms of transport to the placenta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In fetal circulation, the umbilical arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta.

questions.text: What is the duration of short-term memory? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 30-300 seconds

 

Short-term memory lasts for seconds to minutes, hence of the given 4 options, 30-300 seconds is the most appropriate answer.

 

Common classification of memories that divides memories into

 

  1. Short-term memory, which includes memories that last for seconds or at most minutes unless they are converted into longer-term memories 
  2. Intermediate long-term memories, which last for days to weeks but then fade away
  3. Long-term memory, which, once stored, can be recalled up to years or even a lifetime later.

 

“working memory,” that includes mainly short-term memory that is used during the course of intellectual reasoning but is terminated as each stage of the problem is resolved.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Short-term memory lasts for seconds to minutes, storing information temporarily before it is either forgotten or encoded into long-term memory.

 

Additional Information 

 

Memories are frequently classified according to the type of information that is stored. 

 

1. Declarative memory basically means memory of the various details of an integrated thought, such as memory of an important experience that includes – 

  1. Memory of the surroundings, 
  2. Memory of time relationships, 
  3. Memory of causes of the experience, 
  4. Memory of the meaning of the experience, and 
  5. Memory of one’s deductions that were left in the person’s mind.
     

2. Skill memory is frequently associated with motor activities of the person’s body, such as all the skills developed for hitting a tennis ball, including automatic memories to 

  1. Sight the ball, 
  2. Calculate the relationship and speed of the ball to the racquet, and 
  3. Deduce rapidly the motions of the body, the arms, and the racquet required to hit the ball as desired.

choices.text: Cephalic phase of gastric acid secretion
Cerebellar motor coordination before movement execution
Exercise resulting in increased heart rate

questions.text: Which of the following is not an example of feed forward control mechanism? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Exercise resulting in increased heart rate

 

Feedforward mechanism is the control system of our body that anticipates and makes corrective changes without any stimulus. Also called as Anticipatory or Adaptive Control.

 

For instance, some movements of the body occur so rapidly that there is not enough time for nerve signals to travel from the peripheral parts of the body all the way to the brain and then back to the periphery again to control the movement.

The cerebellum uses feed-forward to predict the sensory consequences of a movement before it is executed. This allows for proactive adjustments and smooth, coordinated movements, especially in learned or repetitive movements. The cerebellum helps in estimating the body's future state, compensating for delays in sensory feedback, calculating prediction errors, and adjusting motor commands accordingly

 

Examples include

 

  • Thermoregulation by hypothalamus BEFORE the changes in environmental temperature changes the body's core body temperature
  • Cephalic phase of gastric secretion- Increase in gastric acid secretion on thinking about food
  • THINKING about exercise leading to increase heart rate & respiratory rate
  • Cerebellar motor coordination before movement execution 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Temperature Regulation: Incorrect. This is a feedforward mechanism where the hypothalamus anticipates and adjusts for temperature changes.

 

Option B. Cephalic phase of gastric secretion: Incorrect. This is a feedforward mechanism where thinking about food triggers gastric secretions in anticipation of eating.

 

Option C. Cerebellar action in motor coordination: Incorrect. This is a feedforward mechanism where the cerebellum coordinates movements by predicting the required muscle contractions.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: An individual is in an environment of a temperature of 47°C. What is the mechanism of heat loss? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sweating

 

The mechanism of heat loss in the given case is sweating.

 

As long as skin temperature is greater than the temperature of the surroundings, heat can be lost by radiation and conduction. But when the temperature of the surroundings becomes greater than that of the skin, instead of losing heat, the body gains heat by both radiation and conduction. Under these conditions, the only means by which the body can rid itself of heat is by evaporation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radiation and B. Conduction are effective when the ambient temperature is lower than the body's skin temperature. However, at temperatures higher than the skin temperature, these methods can result in heat gain rather than heat loss.

 

Option C. Convection can aid in heat loss if the air movement can cool the skin, but at high environmental temperatures, its effectiveness is limited.

 

Educational Objective:

 

At high environmental temperatures, the body relies primarily on sweating and evaporation to lose heat and regulate body temperature effectively.

questions.text: Which of the following provides a rapid source of energy for the resynthesis of ATP in exercising muscles? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: D. Phosphocreatine

 

Explanation:

 

Phosphocreatine serves as an immediate source of energy for the resynthesis of adenosine triphosphate (ATP) in muscles during high-intensity, short-duration exercises. It does so by donating a phosphate group to adenosine diphosphate (ADP) to quickly regenerate ATP. This reaction is both rapid and occurs directly at the sites of muscular contraction, which makes phosphocreatine an essential component in maintaining energy supply during the initial phases of exercise before other slower metabolic pathways (like glycolysis and oxidative phosphorylation) increase their output.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A (Glycolysis) is incorrect as glycolysis provides energy at a slower rate compared to phosphocreatine and is typically more involved during moderate-intensity exercises.
  • Option B (Glycogenolysis) is incorrect because it refers to the breakdown of glycogen to glucose, which then must be further processed via glycolysis or other pathways to produce ATP, thus not as immediate as phosphocreatine.
  • Option C (TCA cycle) is also incorrect as the tricarboxylic acid cycle is part of aerobic metabolism, providing energy much slower and is not the primary source during sudden, high-intensity exercise.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phosphocreatine rapidly provides energy for ATP resynthesis in exercising muscles, crucial during the initial stages of high-intensity activities.

choices.text: Bicarbonate in the intracellular compartment
Calcium in the extracellular compartment

questions.text: Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium is mainly due to? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intracellular proteins

 

Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium is mainly due to intracellular proteins.

 

The Gibbs-Donnan effect describes the unequal distribution of Diffusible charged ions on either side of a semipermeable membrane which occurs in the presence of impermeant charged ions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phosphate: While phosphate ions are present in both intracellular and extracellular compartments, they are not the primary cause of the Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium. Their concentrations do not significantly contribute to the electrochemical gradient and osmotic balance in the same way as intracellular proteins do.

 

Option B. Bicarbonate in the intracellular compartment: Bicarbonate ions are crucial for maintaining acid-base balance, but they are not the main factor in establishing the Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium. Their movement across membranes is more related to pH regulation rather than creating an electrochemical gradient due to impermeant ions.

 

Option C. Calcium in the extracellular compartment: Calcium ions are essential for various cellular functions, including muscle contraction and neurotransmission, but they do not play a primary role in the Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium. Their concentration differences across membranes are tightly regulated by channels and pumps, rather than by the presence of impermeant ions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

At Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium,

 

  • On each side of the membrane, each solution will be electrically neutral
  • The product of diffusible ions on one side of the membrane will be equal to the product of diffusible ions on the other side of the membrane
  • The electrochemical gradients produced by unequal distribution of charged ions produces a transmembrane potential difference which can be calculated using the Nernst equation
  • The presence of impermeant ions on one side of the membrane creates an osmotic diffusion gradient attracting water into that compartment.

 

Intracellular proteins are negatively charged non-permeable ions, then distribution of other permeable ions is affected in a predictable way (Donnan Effect) so that at equilibrium their concentration ratios are equal.

questions.text: "Vasopressin escape" in SIADH results due to: (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Downregulation of aquaporin 2 production

 

Vasopressin escape in SIADH (Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion) results due to downregulation of aquaporin 2 production.

 

Downregulation of aquaporin-2 receptors occurs due to prolonged exposure to elevated vasopressin levels resulting in excessive reabsorption of water, despite high serum ADH levels, thus maintaining euvolemia and preventing excessive dilutional hyponatremia in SIADH. This is called as vasopressin escape.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increase in urine osmolarity: Incorrect. Vasopressin escape does not result in an increase in urine osmolarity. Instead, it is characterized by the body's ability to excrete free water to prevent hyponatremia.

 

Option C. Decrease in ADH secretion: Incorrect. Vasopressin escape occurs despite high levels of ADH, not due to a decrease in ADH secretion.

 

Option D. Upregulation of aquaporin 2 production: Incorrect. The condition involves the downregulation, not upregulation, of aquaporin 2 production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Syndrome of inappropriate anti-diuretic hormone (SIADH): Pathogenesis and clinical findings

choices.text: Heparan sulfate
Collagen Type IV

questions.text: The protein in the glomerular basement membrane responsible for charge-dependent filtration is?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Heparan sulfate

 

Explanation

 

The glomerular basement membrane (GBM) is an essential component of the glomerular filtration barrier.

 

The protein in the glomerular basement membrane responsible for charge-dependent filtration is heparan sulfate. As the major determinants of the anionic charge of the GBM, heparan sulfate chains have been thought to impart charge selectivity to the glomerular filtration. It prevents filtration by repelling negatively charged proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fibronectin: While fibronectin is involved in cell adhesion and matrix assembly, it does not primarily contribute to the charge-dependent filtration properties of the GBM.

 

Option C. Collagen Type IV: This type of collagen forms a structural scaffolding in the GBM, providing mechanical strength and stability rather than charge-based selectivity.

 

Option D. Entactin: Also known as nidogen, entactin helps link the network of laminin and collagen IV in the GBM but does not directly influence charge-based filtration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Heparan sulfate is the critical component responsible for the charge-dependent filtration in the glomerular basement membrane. Its negative charge effectively repels similarly charged molecules, preventing their passage into the urine, which is essential for the body's ability to retain vital proteins and other negatively charged substances.

choices.text: Modified Valsalva Maneuver

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with no significant past medical history presents to the emergency department with sudden onset palpitations, lightheadedness, and shortness of breath. On examination, his heart rate is 180 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 70/50 mm Hg. ECG shows a narrow QRS complex tachycardia with a regular rhythm consistent with supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). Despite lying flat and receiving IV fluids, his blood pressure remains low. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Synchronized Cardioversion

 

Explanation:

 

Synchronized cardioversion is the recommended intervention for hemodynamically unstable patients with SVT, as seen in this case where the patient has hypotension and a rapid heart rate. Cardioversion is performed using a defibrillator that synchronizes with the patient’s QRS complex, delivering an electrical shock during ventricular depolarization to avoid inducing ventricular fibrillation. This immediate intervention restores normal sinus rhythm and stabilizes the patient’s hemodynamic status, making it the first-line treatment in hemodynamically unstable patients with tachyarrhythmias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Modified Valsalva Maneuver

The modified Valsalva maneuver is a first-line treatment for stable patients with SVT as it increases vagal tone and can terminate the tachycardia. However, it is not appropriate for patients who are hemodynamically unstable, as in this case, where immediate intervention is necessary.

 

Option C. Adenosine IV

Adenosine is the drug of choice for stable SVT, acting by transiently blocking atrioventricular nodal conduction and often terminating the arrhythmia. In this unstable patient with hypotension, however, immediate cardioversion is preferred to rapidly stabilize the heart rhythm.

 

Option D. Metoprolol IV

Metoprolol, a beta-blocker, can be used to control the rate in various tachyarrhythmias, including SVT. However, its onset is slower, and it is not the treatment of choice in hemodynamically unstable patients where rapid rhythm control is needed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Synchronized cardioversion is the first-line treatment for hemodynamically unstable patients with narrow or wide complex tachyarrhythmias, including SVT. It provides immediate rhythm control by delivering an electrical shock synchronized with the patient’s cardiac cycle, stabilizing the heart rhythm and improving the patient's clinical condition.

questions.text: What does the zero pressure indicate in the pressure-volume curve? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Functional residual capacity

 

The pressure-volume curve represents the relationship between the lung volumes and the transpulmonary pressures. Zero pressure in this context usually refers to the point where the pressure inside the lungs is equal to the atmospheric pressure, indicating a state of no net airflow. This point corresponds to the functional residual capacity (FRC), which is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal, passive exhalation.

 

  • Functional Residual Capacity (FRC): It is the volume of air present in the lungs at the end of passive expiration. This capacity includes the expiratory reserve volume (ERV) and the residual volume (RV). FRC is an important measure because it represents the balance point between the elastic recoil forces of the lungs and the chest wall.

 

 

The functional residual capacity is the volume of the air that remains in the lungs after normal expiration. The normal value is about 2.5 liters.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Residual volume is the air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort.

 

Option C: Tidal volume is the amount of air that moves in during each inspiration or the amount of air that moves out with each expiration, during quiet breathing.

 

Option D: Inspiratory reserve volume is the air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in addition to the tidal volume.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The zero pressure in the pressure-volume curve indicates the functional residual capacity, which is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after a normal exhalation.

questions.text: Identify the pelvic diaphragm in the picture given below? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A

 

Explanation:

 

The structure marked "A" is the levator ani muscle which is part of the pelvic diaphragm.

 

The levator ani is the principal muscle of the pelvic floor and is composed of three parts: the puborectalis, the pubococcygeus, and the iliococcygeus. It is primarily innervated by the pudendal nerve and the S4 nerve root.

 

 

 

The structure marked in the given image are:

 

A. Levator ani

B. Sphincter ani externus

C. Obturator muscle

D. Perianal fascia

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sphincter Ani Externus (External Anal Sphincter): This is a circular muscle that surrounds the anus. It's located below the level of the levator ani. It is innervated by the pudendal nerve, allowing for voluntary control over defecation.

 

Option C. Obturator Muscle: This term often refers to two muscles - obturator externus and obturator internus. They are situated on either side of the obturator membrane in the pelvis. Obturator Externus: Obturator nerve and Obturator Internus: Nerve to obturator internus (a branch of the sacral plexus).

 

Option D. Perianal Fascia: The perianal fascia is not a muscle but is the connective tissue located in the perianal region, around the anus. It's part of the deeper layers of the skin in this region.  It's associated with various potential spaces that can become sites of abscess formation if there's an infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The levator ani muscle is a key component of the pelvic diaphragm, supporting pelvic organs and aiding in fecal continence, illustrating its critical role in both pelvic structure and function.

questions.text: A boy presented with a fever and chills. Rapid test was positive for specific antigen HRP-2. Which of the following species of Plasmodium is the most likely causative agent? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Plasmodium falciparum

 

Patient with given clinical symptoms and the HRP-2 positivity points to diagnosis of P. falciparum malaria.

 

This test is based on the detection of histidine-rich protein-2 (HRP-2), produced only by the asexual forms of Plasmodium falciparum, present on the surface of RBCs. It can detect only Plasmodium falciparum HRP-2 antigen but not the other three species of Plasmodium. Test remains positive until 2 weeks after the cure.

 

 

Another Kit test is Parasite lactate dehydrogenase (p LDH) which can detect all four Plasmodium species that infect humans.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Plasmodium malariae: Not detected by the HRP-2 test.

 

Option C. Plasmodium vivax and Option D. Plasmodium ovale: Also not detected by the HRP-2 test. They would be identified by other rapid tests targeting different antigens like pLDH (Plasmodium Lactate Dehydrogenase).

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a rapid diagnosis of Plasmodium falciparum infection, the detection of the HRP-2 antigen is critical. This test is specific to P. falciparum, aiding in rapid treatment decisions crucial for preventing the severe complications associated with this malaria species.

choices.text: Candidiasis of the esophagus

questions.text: A 38-year-old man with a history of untreated HIV presents to the clinic with complaints of difficulty swallowing, and a weight loss of 10 pounds over the past two months. His latest CD4 count is 180 cells/µL. The patient is concerned about the progression of his HIV to AIDS. Which of the following is not considered an AIDS-defining illness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Oral candidiasis

 

Explanation:

 

Oral candidiasis, commonly known as thrush, is frequently observed in individuals with HIV due to immune suppression but is not considered an AIDS-defining illness. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), AIDS-defining conditions are specific infections or cancers that signal the progression of HIV infection to AIDS. Severe forms of candidiasis, such as those affecting the esophagus, bronchi, or lungs, are included in the list of AIDS-defining illnesses, but oral involvement alone does not qualify.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candidiasis of the esophagus: This is considered an AIDS-defining illness as it indicates a significant degree of immune compromise, often requiring antifungal treatment and marking the progression of HIV infection to AIDS.

 

Option B. Kaposi sarcoma: This is an AIDS-defining cancer associated with human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8). It commonly presents in immunocompromised patients, particularly those with advanced HIV infection.

 

Option D. Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia: This is a common opportunistic infection in AIDS patients, often presenting with severe respiratory symptoms and hypoxia. It is one of the hallmark infections used to define the transition to AIDS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oral candidiasis is commonly seen in patients with HIV as a marker of immune suppression but is not considered an AIDS-defining illness. AIDS-defining illnesses include more severe infections and cancers such as esophageal candidiasis, Kaposi sarcoma, and Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia, which indicate advanced immunosuppression and progression to AIDS. Understanding these distinctions helps guide clinical decisions and management in HIV-infected patients.

choices.text: Thick layer of fibrin lining the alveoli
Pulmonary artery hypertrophy with increased resistance

questions.text: A 56-year-old man was diagnosed with COVID-19 and was put on mechanical ventilation. He passed away after a week. What is the likely post-mortem change seen in the lungs? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thick layer of fibrin lining the alveoli

 

In a patient with severe COVID-19 who was on mechanical ventilation, the likely post-mortem change seen in the lungs is, thick layer of fibrin lining the alveoli.

 

COVID-19 is known to cause severe respiratory illness, and in severe cases, patients may require mechanical ventilation. One of the characteristic features of severe COVID-19 pneumonia is the development of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). ARDS is characterized by diffuse alveolar damage, including the accumulation of fibrin-rich hyaline membranes lining the alveolar walls. This can result in the formation of a thick layer of fibrin lining the alveoli, leading to impaired gas exchange and respiratory failure.

 

While acute and chronic alveolar hemorrhage, perivascular cuffing, and pulmonary artery hypertrophy with increased resistance may be seen in other respiratory diseases, they are not typically associated with severe COVID-19 pneumonia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute and chronic alveolar hemorrhage: This may be seen in conditions like vasculitis or certain types of pneumonia but is not a hallmark of severe COVID-19.

 

Option C. Perivascular cuffing: This refers to lymphocytic infiltration around blood vessels and is more common in viral myocarditis and certain chronic lung diseases.

 

Option D. Pulmonary artery hypertrophy with increased resistance: This is typically associated with chronic pulmonary hypertension and not an immediate feature of severe COVID-19 pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with severe COVID-19, especially those who have been on mechanical ventilation, the likely post-mortem finding in the lungs is a thick layer of fibrin lining the alveoli, indicative of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and severe diffuse alveolar damage.

questions.text: A patient presented with a prolonged fever of unknown origin (PUO), raising suspicion of brucellosis. To confirm the diagnosis, various dilutions of the patient's serum sample are prepared for a standard agglutination test. The outcome is as follows: No agglutination is observed at serum dilutions of 1:20 and 1:40, while positive agglutination occurs at dilutions of 1:80 and 1:160. What factor is accountable for the lack of agglutination in the initial two dilutions? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Antibody excess

 

  • Marrack proposed the lattice hypothesis → Multivalent antigens combine with Bivalent antibodies
  • Lattice is formed only when antigen and antibodies are in proportion.
  • If antigen or antibodies ,any of them is in excess - there is no lattice formation
  • The absence of a positive test result in the initial two tubes can be attributed to the prozone phenomenon.
  • In this scenario, there is an excess of antibodies in comparison to antigens, which results in a lack of robust or noticeable precipitation.

 

Zone phenomenon:

 

  1. Prozone = Ab excess = Absent
  2. Zone of equivalence = Proper proportion = Peak
  3. Post zone = Ag excess = Absent

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Incorrect antigen: If the antigen were incorrect, there would be no agglutination at any dilution.

 

Option B. Incorrect antibody: If the antibody were incorrect, there would be no agglutination at any dilution.

 

Option D. Antigen excess: Antigen excess would cause a postzone phenomenon, not observed here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The prozone phenomenon, where antibody excess prevents agglutination, can account for the lack of agglutination in low dilution samples.

choices.text: Cobalt blue with trypan blue for corneal ulcer
Cobalt green with Rose Bengal stain for corneal opacity
Cobalt blue with fluorescein stain for corneal ulcer
Cobalt blue with lissamine green for corneal abrasion

questions.text: Which of the following accurately pairs the  diagnostic stain with the corneal condition it indicates? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cobalt blue with fluorescein stain for corneal ulcer

 

This is the correct match. Fluorescein, when used with a cobalt blue light, stains areas of corneal epithelial loss, highlighting defects such as corneal ulcers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cobalt blue with trypan blue for corneal ulcer: Trypan blue is generally used in cataract surgery to stain the anterior capsule, not for diagnosing corneal ulcers.

 

Option B. Cobalt green with Rose Bengal stain for corneal opacity: Rose Bengal stain is actually used to detect damage to the eye's surface cells, particularly in cases of dry eye where these cells are more vulnerable. 

 

Option D. Cobalt blue with lissamine green for corneal abrasion: Lissamine green stains areas of cell loss or damage on the surface of the eye, such as in cases of corneal abrasion or dry eye. It’s used under white light rather than cobalt blue light.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Fluorescein stain under cobalt blue light remains a standard and effective method for diagnosing corneal ulcers due to its ability to vividly highlight areas of epithelial loss.

choices.text: Western blot
Real time PCR

questions.text: Which of the following method is employed to measure the viral load? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Real time PCR

 

A real-time polymerase chain reaction (real-time PCR, or qPCR) is a laboratory technique of molecular biology based on the polymerase chain reaction (PCR). It monitors the amplification of a targeted DNA molecule during the PCR (i.e., in real time). Fluorescence is measured after each cycle and the intensity of the fluorescent signal reflects the momentary amount of DNA amplicons in the sample at that specific time. Commonly used for viral load quantification of HIV, hepatitis C virus, hepatitis B virus, and CMV.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. ELISA: Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay is primarily used to detect antigens or antibodies in a sample and is not used for measuring viral load.

 

Option B. Western blot: This technique is used to detect specific proteins in a sample and is not used for measuring viral load.

 

Option D. Immunoelectrophoresis: This method is used to separate and identify proteins based on their antigen-antibody interactions and is not used for measuring viral load.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Real-time PCR measure viral load
  • Western blotting – detects protein.
  • ELISA - detect antigens of infectious agents
  • Immuno electrophoresis – separates antigen following antigen antibody reaction

questions.text: Vaccine that requires strain change due to evolving organism is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Influenza

 

 

The influenza vaccine is unique among vaccines because it requires periodic updates or strain changes almost every year. This necessity is due to the evolving nature of the influenza virus, particularly the frequent antigenic changes in its surface glycoproteins (hemagglutinin and neuraminidase). These changes can occur through two primary mechanisms:

 

  • Antigenic Drift: Minor changes that occur gradually over time as the virus replicates. These small genetic mutations can alter the antigenic properties of the virus, necessitating updates to the vaccine to maintain its effectiveness.
  • Antigenic Shift: Less frequent but more significant changes that can lead to the emergence of a completely new influenza virus subtype. This can potentially lead to pandemics if the new subtype spreads widely and the population has little to no immunity against it.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Diphtheria: The vaccine for diphtheria does not require frequent updates or strain changes. The causative bacterium (Corynebacterium diphtheriae) does not exhibit the same level of antigenic variation that necessitates vaccine modification.

 

Option C. Polio: Polio vaccines target stable viral antigens of the poliovirus, which do not undergo frequent antigenic changes, thus not requiring periodic strain updates.

 

Option D. Typhoid: Typhoid vaccines, such as those for Salmonella Typhi, also do not require frequent changes in formulation, as the bacterial antigens are relatively stable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The influenza vaccine must be updated regularly to match the antigenically evolving influenza virus strains, primarily due to antigenic drift (gradual) and shift (drastic). This adaptation is essential to enhance vaccine effectiveness and control the spread of flu each season, highlighting the dynamic challenge of influenza virus surveillance and vaccine formulation.

questions.text: The patient visiting the outpatient department exhibits skin manifestations linked to a disease that includes Raynaud’s phenomenon. What is this skin manifestation shown below? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Salt and pepper pigmentation.

 

  • The presented clinical scenario indicates systemic sclerosis, a complex autoimmune condition of uncertain origin with diverse clinical manifestations.
  • It leads to considerable disability and mortality, affecting nearly all organs.
  • The defining feature of systemic sclerosis is scleroderma, characterized by thickened and indurated skin.

 

Systemic sclerosis

 

It also presents with typical skin manifestations of Raynaud phenomenon, which include the characteristic white discoloration of the fingers due to vasospasm and bluish discoloration of the fingertips as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • The skin has a salt-and-pepper appearance when there is a loss of pigmentation, which is most noticeable on the upper back (as given in the question), chest, and scalp.
  • Sclerodactyly and sclerosis extending proximal to the metacarpophalangeal joints with or without contractures.

 

 

  • Loss of fingertip pulp
  • Vasculopathic ulcers over the bony prominences
  • Puffy fingers in early disease
  • Severe flexion contractures
  • Expressionless facies, mat-like telangiectasias, microstomia, perioral furrowing, and a beak-like nose can be seen as shown in the image below

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Poikiloderma is a skin disorder characterized by (ATP)

 

  • Atrophy
  • Telangiectasias
  • Pigment abnormalities Hypo and hyper

 

 

It is seen in ionizing radiation-damaged skin and Dermatomyositis.

 

Option C: Sometimes the color of the hair can change to white in the amelanotic lesions of vitiligo. It is known as leukotrichia.

 

Option D: Sharply demarcated depigmented macules are a hallmark of vitiligo. It results from the loss of melanocytes.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

'Salt and Pepper pigmentation' is a cutaneous manifestation often seen in systemic sclerosis, a condition which also commonly presents with Raynaud’s phenomenon.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 56 page no 56.4

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine, 21st edition 2779

questions.text: A patient has been brought with severe bleeding to your ER. His blood group is unknown. Fresh frozen plasma from which of the following blood groups can be given? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) AB

 

FFP from AB blood group can be given to this patient since the universal plasma donor is AB. AB plasma does not contain antibodies against antigens on RBCs of AB blood group.

 

Here, the question is about fresh frozen plasma transfusion and not about the packed red cells.

 

Had the question been about packed RBCs then in case of emergency packed cell blood transfusion with unknown blood group, O Rh-negative blood (universal donor) is transfused. It is preferred because it lacks the A and B and Rh antigens. Hence, it cannot be hemolyzed by anti-A, anti-B or anti-D antibodies in the recipient's blood.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Stop MDT give thalidomide
Stop MDT, start systemic corticosteroids
Continue MDT, start systemic steroids

questions.text: In a case where a patient undergoing multi-drug therapy (MDT) experiences a deterioration of existing lesions and nerve complications, what course of action would you consider taking next? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Continue MDT, start systemic steroids

 

The situation described, where pre-existing lesions worsen during multi-drug therapy (MDT) for leprosy, indicates a type 1 lepra reaction. In managing this condition, the recommended approach would be to continue MDT while initiating systemic steroid treatment.

 

  • Type 1 lepra reactions are marked by inflammation of existing skin lesions, leading to symptoms such as edema, redness, and pain. While ulcers are uncommon, the development of new lesions is exceptionally rare. Additionally, acute neuritis may occur, presenting with tenderness and impairment of both motor and sensory functions.
  • In patients with lepra reactions, MDT is never discontinued. NSAIDs and oral steroids can be added to treat pain.
  • Thalidomide is considered the gold standard for treating severe cases of type-2 lepra reaction or erythema nodosum leprosum. However, it is not the Drug of Choice due to its high cost and potential for adverse drug reactions. In type II lepra reactions, patients may experience systemic symptoms such as iritis, orchitis, and the appearance of new skin lesions.

 

Type I & II lepra reactions:

 

(ENL = Erythema Nodosum Leprosum)

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Stop MDT give thalidomide

  • Thalidomide is an immunomodulatory drug that may be used in certain conditions, like leprosy and its complications.
  • However, stopping MDT is not recommended as it is crucial to continue the treatment of the primary disease. Thalidomide is not used as treatment for Type 1 lepra reaction in leprosy.

 

Option B. Continue MDT, start thalidomide –

While MDT should be continued, thalidomide is not typically used for nerve complications. It's used primarily for severe or recurrent erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL) Type 2 Lepra reaction, which is an immune-mediated complication of leprosy.

 

Option C. Stop MDT, start systemic corticosteroids –

  • Stopping MDT is not advised as the antibiotics in MDT are essential for treating the bacterial infection causing the disease.
  • The MDT should be continued to prevent the development of drug resistance and to adequately treat the underlying infection.

 

Option D. Continue MDT, start systemic steroids -

  • This is the correct management for a leprosy patient with nerve damage, which is likely due to an immune reaction called a leprosy reaction. Systemic corticosteroids are used to control the inflammation and prevent further nerve damage.
  • MDT should be continued to treat the underlying infection.
  • The reason for selecting option D is that systemic corticosteroids are effective in treating acute nerve inflammation and can prevent further damage while continuing MDT ensures that the infection is adequately treated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the case of nerve complications in a patient undergoing multi-drug therapy for conditions like leprosy, the appropriate course of action is to continue the anti-microbial therapy and start systemic steroids to manage the inflammatory reaction causing nerve damage.

 

Reference:  Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Chapter 28 Page no 28.5, 28.12, 28.16

questions.text: RNAi acts through? (INICET May 2021
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Knock down

 

Explanation:

 

Gene knock down is when function of the gene present is suppressed by inhibiting or degrading the target mRNA so that it cannot form its protein. This is also known as post transcriptional gene silencing or RNA interference (RNAi). This is mediated by micro RNA (miRNA) or small interfering RNA (siRNA) which are small 20-27 nucleotides long non-coding RNAs. miRNA based RNAi involves the uses of three enzymes DROSHA, PASHA and DICER.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Knock out: This involves removing or taking a gene out, resulting in a complete loss of gene function.

 

Option C. Knock in: This involves inserting a gene into a specific location within the genome.

 

Option D. Knock up: This term is not used in the context of gene manipulation.

 

Educational Objective:


RNA interference (RNAi) acts through gene knock down by suppressing the function of a gene via degradation or inhibition of its target mRNA, preventing protein formation.

 

Ref- Harper 31st e/p 346-348

questions.text: What is the photostress test used to differentiate between?  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Macula and optic nerve disease

 

  • Photo stress test helps differentiate between diseases involving the macula and optic nerve.
  • This test is particularly useful in early macular diseases like central serous retinopathy.
  • One eye is covered and the patient is asked to read the smallest line on a near chart.
  • A bright light is shone into the eye for 15 seconds, and the patient is asked to read the line again.
  • The time taken to recover is noted, and the test is repeated with the other eye.
  • In normal people and patients with optic nerve disease, recovery time is not affected.
  • In patients with macular disease, recovery time is prolonged, usually more than one-third of the normal recovery time.
  • Photoreceptor damage and delayed visual pigment regeneration process contribute to prolonged recovery time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cataract and glaucoma: The photostress test is not designed to differentiate between cataract and glaucoma. Cataract affects the lens, while glaucoma primarily affects the optic nerve and intraocular pressure.

 

Option C. Lens and cornea: The photostress test does not help in differentiating between lens and corneal pathologies. Issues with the lens (e.g., cataracts) and cornea are typically diagnosed with slit-lamp examination and other tests.

 

Option D. Retina and vitreal pathologies: The photostress test is not specifically used to differentiate between retinal and vitreal pathologies. Other diagnostic methods, such as ophthalmoscopy, fundus photography, and optical coherence tomography (OCT), are more appropriate for these conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The photostress test is a simple and effective diagnostic tool used to differentiate between macular diseases and optic nerve diseases, based on the recovery time of vision following bright light exposure.

questions.text: Which of the following can alter the gene expression by methylation and acetylation but not change the gene sequence? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Epigenetics

 

Epigenetics refers to the study of changes in gene function that are heritable through cell division (mitotic and meiotic) but do not involve alterations in the DNA sequence. Epigenetic modifications can regulate gene expression by altering the accessibility of transcription factors to the DNA.

 

Mechanisms of Epigenetics:

 

  1. Histone Acetylation: The acetylation of specific lysine residues in core histones (H3 and H4) leads to an open chromatin structure, facilitating the access of transcription factors to the DNA and thereby promoting gene transcription.
  2. DNA Methylation: The addition of methyl groups to cytosine residues, particularly at CpG dinucleotides within gene promoters, leads to chromatin condensation and transcriptional repression.

Epigenetic modifications such as methylation and acetylation play crucial roles in regulating gene expression and can influence various biological processes, including development, differentiation, and carcinogenesis, without altering the underlying DNA sequence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mutation: Mutations involve changes in the DNA sequence, such as substitutions, deletions, or insertions, which can affect gene function and expression.

 

Option C. Translocation: This refers to the rearrangement of parts between nonhomologous chromosomes, which involves changes in the DNA sequence and can disrupt gene function.

 

Option D. Inversion: An inversion is a chromosomal rearrangement in which a segment of a chromosome is reversed end to end, involving changes in the DNA sequence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epigenetics involves modifications such as methylation and acetylation that regulate gene expression without changing the DNA sequence, playing a crucial role in various biological processes and diseases.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presents in surgery OPD with midline swelling in the neck. The swelling moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue. What is the likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thyroglossal cyst

 

  • Pathology – Remnant of thyroglossal duct
  • Most common site – midline à Subhyoid
  • C/F – Presents in 2nd /3rd decade of life as midline neck swelling which moves up on tongue protrusion and on deglutition.
  • Treatment - Sistrunk’s operation
  • Long standing thyroglossal cyst has a risk of papillary carcinoma thyroid

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Branchial cyst: Failure of obliteration of branchial cleft. Cystic swelling (soft)- typically in a teenager. Swelling at upper 1/3rd + middle 1/3rd junction of sternocleidomastoid.

 

 

Option C. Plunging ranula: Presents as Swelling in floor of mouth, Fluctuation present, Brilliant transillumination.

 

 

Option D. Dermoid cyst: Caused when skin and skin structures become trapped during fetal development.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A midline neck swelling that moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue is characteristic of a thyroglossal cyst, which is a remnant of the thyroglossal duct.
  • The treatment is typically surgical removal via the Sistrunk procedure.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus is being evaluated for medications to manage their condition and prevent renal complications. Which of the following drugs will not delay progression of renal disease? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hydrochlorothiazide

 

Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic primarily used to treat hypertension and edema. It is not specifically known to delay the progression of renal disease in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. While it helps in managing blood pressure, it does not have the protective renal effects seen with other medications listed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SGLT2 inhibitors: These drugs, such as dapagliflozin and empagliflozin, have been shown to provide renal protection by reducing the progression of kidney disease in patients with type 2 diabetes. They work by decreasing glucose reabsorption in the kidneys, leading to osmotic diuresis and reduced glomerular hyperfiltration.

 

Option B. Finerenone: This is a non-steroidal mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist (MRA) approved for the treatment of chronic kidney disease in type 2 diabetes. It helps to reduce albuminuria and slows the progression of renal disease.

 

Option D. Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs): ARBs, such as losartan and valsartan, are well-known for their renal protective effects. They help reduce proteinuria and slow the progression of diabetic nephropathy by blocking the effects of angiotensin II on the kidneys.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydrochlorothiazide does not delay the progression of renal disease in patients with type 2 diabetes. In contrast, SGLT2 inhibitors, finerenone, and angiotensin receptor blockers are all known to provide renal protection and slow the progression of diabetic kidney disease.

questions.text: Which anticoagulant is used for electrolyte estimation? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lithium Heparin

 

  • Lithium Heparin is preferred for electrolyte testing because it does not interfere with the measurement of most electrolytes, such as sodium, potassium, and chloride. It is also the best anticoagulant for tests that require accurate pH, blood gases, electrolytes, and ionized calcium levels.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. EDTA: While EDTA is widely used for hematological examinations, it is not suitable for electrolyte estimation because it can chelate calcium and interfere with other ion measurements.

 

Option B. Citrate: Sodium citrate is primarily used for coagulation studies (e.g., PT, PTT) because it binds calcium ions to prevent clotting, but it is not ideal for electrolyte estimation.

 

Option C. Sodium Fluoride: Sodium fluoride is used primarily for glucose and lactate testing because it inhibits glycolysis, but it is not appropriate for electrolyte testing as it can interfere with the results.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient presents with erectile dysfunction and bilateral leg pain that worsens with rest. The patient reports a history of smoking and high blood pressure. Physical examination reveals reduced sensation in both legs and weak pulses in the feet. Identify the location of the lesion? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aortoiliac bifurcation

 

  • Bilateral lower limb claudication, weak pulses, and erectile dysfunction are suggestive of Leriche’s syndrome.
  • Leriche’s syndrome is a rare form of peripheral arterial disease caused by the obstruction or narrowing of the abdominal aorta, specifically at the aortoiliac bifurcation.
  • This is the location where the abdominal aorta splits into the left and right common iliac arteries.
  • Leriche syndrome (or aortoiliac occlusive disease) results from a blockage at this bifurcation.
  • Patients with this condition experience claudication (pain in the buttocks and thighs), erectile dysfunction (because of reduced blood flow to the pelvis), and decreased pulses in the legs.
  • Given the combination of symptoms, this location is the most plausible for the lesion in the presented case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilateral popliteal arteries: Obstruction or narrowing of these arteries could cause pain in the calves or feet, especially after walking or exercise. It would not explain the symptoms of erectile dysfunction.

 

Option B. Bilateral internal iliac arteries: The internal iliac arteries supply various pelvic organs, including the prostate, bladder, and rectum. While occlusion of the internal iliac arteries might explain some of the pelvic symptoms like erectile dysfunction, it's not likely to cause bilateral leg pain and reduced sensation in both legs.

 

Option D. Bilateral femoral arteries: The femoral arteries supply blood to the thighs and lower legs. Obstruction in these arteries can cause pain in the thighs or calves during walking or exercise. However, this wouldn't typically result in erectile dysfunction.

 

  • Given the combination of erectile dysfunction, bilateral leg pain that worsens with rest, and the reduced pulses in the feet, the aortoiliac bifurcation (option C) is the most likely location of the lesion, consistent with Leriche syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Leriche syndrome, also known as aortoiliac occlusive disease, involves obstruction at the aortoiliac bifurcation, leading to symptoms like claudication, erectile dysfunction, and decreased lower limb pulses.

choices.text: Rest pain is seen more in the night
Pain in intermittent claudication comes at first step of walking.
The clinical stem does not reflect the site of peripheral arterial obstruction

questions.text: Which of the statements regarding claudication pain is incorrect? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pain in intermittent claudication comes at first step of walking.

 

Intermittent claudication is characterized by muscle pain (ache, cramp, numbness or sense of fatigue), classically in the calf muscle, which occurs during exercise and is relieved by a short period of rest (< 5 minutes). The pain does not typically start with the first step but develops after a predictable distance of walking.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rest pain is seen more in the night: True. Rest pain is a more severe symptom of peripheral artery disease (PAD). It typically indicates more advanced disease than intermittent claudication. This pain occurs when the limb is at rest, often at night due to the decreased perfusion that results from the horizontal position of the limb. It often awakens the patient from sleep and can be relieved by hanging the leg over the bed or walking.

 

Option C. Most common cause is atheroma: True. The most common cause of intermittent claudication is atherosclerosis (plaque or atheroma formation) in the peripheral arteries. This reduces blood flow to the muscles during activity, causing pain.

 

Option D. The clinical stem does not reflect the site of peripheral arterial obstruction: True. The site of pain (e.g., calf, thigh) does not always directly correlate with the level of arterial obstruction. For instance, while calf pain is often due to femoropopliteal disease, it can also be caused by aortoiliac disease. However, the location of claudication pain can provide a clue to the level of disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The incorrect statement among the provided options is that pain in intermittent claudication occurs at the first step of walking.

choices.text: Ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in UL97 phosphotransferase gene
CMV can be cultured in vitro in any mammalian cell
Commonest manifestation of CMV associated disease is watery diarrhea
UL54 mutated CMV strains do not show cross resistance to Foscarnet

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding CMV? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in UL97 phosphotransferase gene

 

Resistance to ganciclovir (GCV) most commonly occurs due to mutations in the UL97 phosphotransferase gene.

 

Viral UL97 kinase and UL54 DNA polymerase gene mutations are well-documented mechanisms of resistance to current antivirals. The UL97 kinase normally phosphorylates serine and threonine residues of various cellular and viral proteins, and is required for efficient CMV replication. This kinase also effects the initial phosphorylation of GCV that is required for antiviral activity, and UL97 mutations that impair this phosphorylation are the preferred mechanism of GCV resistance.

 

UL54 mutations can confer resistance to all current drugs and may emerge after prolonged GCV therapy to increase the level of resistance conferred by a pre-existing UL97 mutation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Human CMV replicates in vitro only in human fibroblasts, although the virus is often isolated from epithelial cells of the host.

 

Option C: CMV infection is mostly subclinical. In immunocompromised individuals, CMV can cause various manifestations, including retinitis, colitis, esophagitis, pneumonitis, and encephalitis, but watery diarrhea is not the most common manifestation.

 

Option D: UL54 mutations can confer resistance to ganciclovir, cidofovir, and foscamet. These mutations affect the viral DNA polymerase, leading to cross-resistance to multiple antiviral drugs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CMV is ganciclovir resistance is due to mutation in the UL97 phosphotransferase gene. This gene is responsible for the initial phosphorylation of ganciclovir, and mutations here can prevent the drug's activation, leading to resistance. Human CMV replicates in vitro only in human fibroblasts, and UL54 mutations can confer cross-resistance to multiple antiviral drugs, including foscarnet. CMV infections are mostly subclinical, and the common manifestations in immunocompromised patients are not typically watery diarrhea.

questions.text: Calculate the percentage of burns in a patient that presented to the  emergency with flame burn injury covering the entire  chest and abdomen, the entire right upper limb and full circumference of the  right thigh.(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 36

 

To calculate the percentage of body surface area affected by burns, the Rule of Nines is often used in adults. This method divides the body into sections that represent 9% (or multiples thereof) of the body surface area.

 

As per the case scenario given :

 

  • Chest and abdomen: 18%
  • Right upper limb: 9%
  • Right thigh: 9%

 

Total = 18% (chest and abdomen) + 9% (right upper limb) + 9% (right thigh) = 36%

 

Educational Objective:

 

This calculation as per the case scenario and Wallace rule of 9 results in a total burned body surface area of 36%, which corresponds to option B.

 

Rule of Nine

choices.text: It is recommended for patients with colorectal cancer

questions.text: True statement about teduglutide is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is a GLP- 2 analogue

 

Teduglutide is a glucagon-like peptide-2 (GLP-2) analogue. It is used to treat short bowel syndrome in adults and works by promoting the growth of the intestinal lining, thereby improving nutrient absorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Its half-life is 6 - 8 hours: The half-life of teduglutide is actually around 2 hours, not 6-8 hours.

 

Option C. It is administered orally: Teduglutide is not administered orally; it is administered via subcutaneous injection.

 

Option D. It is recommended for patients with colorectal cancer: Teduglutide is not recommended for patients with colorectal cancer. It is specifically approved for use in patients with short bowel syndrome.

 

Therefore, the true statement about teduglutide is that it is a GLP-2 analogue, making option A the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Teduglutide is a GLP-2 analogue used to treat short bowel syndrome. It is administered via subcutaneous injection and has a half-life of about 2 hours. It is not recommended for patients with colorectal cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drugs is associated with the increased risk of fractures? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Rosiglitazone

 

Rosiglitazone, a drug belonging to the class of thiazolidinediones, has been associated with an increased risk of bone fractures. The mechanism behind this is not fully understood, but it is thought that thiazolidinediones might interfere with bone metabolism (PPARγ agonist), leading to decreased bone mineral density which can increase the risk of fractures, especially in postmenopausal women.

 

Other Options:
