Option B. Liraglutide: It is a GLP-1 receptor agonist used in the treatment of type 2 diabetes. There is no strong evidence linking liraglutide to an increased risk of fractures.

 

Option C. Voglibose: It is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor which delays the absorption of carbohydrates from the intestines. It has not been primarily associated with an increased risk of fractures.

 

Option D. Canagliflozin: It is one of the SGLT2 inhibitors that works by removing glucose through the urine. While there have been some discussions about bone density changes with SGLT2 inhibitors, canagliflozin specifically has had mixed results in studies regarding fracture risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glitazones like rosiglitazone and pioglitazone are associated with following adverse effects:

 

  • Hepatotoxicity
  • Retention of sodium and water
  • Risk of osteoporotic fractures

 

SGLT-2 inhibitors like canagliflozin is also associated with increased risk of fractures but the incidence is much lower than that with glitazones.

choices.text: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient has proteinuria. Looking at the immunofluorescence image below, what is the diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lupus nephritis

 

The given immunofluorescence staining of the kidney biopsy specimen shows positive staining for fibrinogen, IgG, IgA, IgM, C1q, C3, λ chain, and k light chain. This is known as full-house effect. It is seen in lupus nephritis.

 

Six patterns of lupus nephritis

 

  1. Class I - Minimal lesions - deposits within the mesangium positive for IgG and C3.
  2. Class II – Mesangial lupus nephritis - Granular mesangial deposits of IgG and C3; sometimes IgA and IgM are also present in the deposits.
  3. Class III – Focal segmental lupus nephritis - Subendothelial and subepithelial deposits of IgG, often with IgM or IgA and C3, are seen.
  4. Class IV – Diffuse lupus nephritis – Most severe and most common. Deposits in the mesangium and in the subendothelial region which on immunofluorescence are positive for IgG; sometimes also for IgA or IgM, and C3.
  5. Class V – Membranous Lupus Nephritis - subendothelial deposits of immune complexes containing IgG, IgM and C3
  6. Class VI – Sclerosing Lupus nephritis - End-stage kidney of SLE. Most glomeruli are sclerosed and hyalinised and there may be remnants of preceding lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS): This does not typically show a full-house pattern on immunofluorescence. FSGS is usually characterized by segmental glomerular scarring and may show focal deposits of IgM and C3.

 

Option B. Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSG): This condition typically shows deposits of IgG and C3 in a "starry sky" pattern on immunofluorescence but does not display a full-house pattern.

 

Option C. Goodpasture syndrome: This typically shows linear deposits of IgG along the glomerular basement membrane, without the full-house pattern seen in lupus nephritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The full-house effect on immunofluorescence (positive staining for IgG, IgA, IgM, C1q, C3, λ chain, and κ light chain) is a hallmark of lupus nephritis.

 

Ref: Robbins Pathologic basis of disease 8th edition, Pg 409-410

questions.text: A 63-year-old man presents to the neurology clinic with complaints of difficulty walking, muscle stiffness, and a tremor in his right hand that worsens when at rest. His wife reports that he has become slower in his movements over the past year and occasionally experiences a shuffling gait. Neurological examination reveals bradykinesia, cogwheel rigidity, and a resting tremor in both hands. An MRI of the brain shows atrophy of the substantia nigra, which is marked in the diagram below. Which of the following diseases is most closely associated with degeneration of this structure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Parkinson’s disease

 

Explanation:

 

Parkinson’s disease is primarily associated with the degeneration of the substantia nigra, a structure in the midbrain responsible for producing dopamine, which is essential for coordinating smooth and purposeful movements. The loss of dopamine-producing neurons leads to the characteristic motor symptoms of Parkinson’s disease, including bradykinesia, muscle rigidity, and resting tremors. The substantia nigra appears pigmented due to neuromelanin, but in Parkinson’s disease, this pigmentation is reduced due to neuronal loss. The disease progresses gradually and often leads to significant motor impairment and a distinct shuffling gait.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Progressive supranuclear palsy: This is a neurodegenerative disorder that primarily affects the brainstem and basal ganglia, leading to postural instability, vertical gaze palsy, and bradykinesia. While it shares some symptoms with Parkinson’s disease, it does not specifically target the substantia nigra as the main site of degeneration.

 

Option B. Multiple system atrophy: This neurodegenerative disorder affects multiple areas of the brain, including the basal ganglia, cerebellum, and autonomic nervous system, but does not specifically target the substantia nigra as the primary site of degeneration as seen in Parkinson’s disease.

 

Option D. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS): ALS primarily affects the motor neurons in the brain and spinal cord, leading to progressive muscle weakness, atrophy, and spasticity. It does not involve the substantia nigra, and patients do not typically present with parkinsonian features such as tremors and rigidity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parkinson’s disease is characterized by the degeneration of the substantia nigra, resulting in dopamine deficiency that manifests as bradykinesia, muscle rigidity, and resting tremors. The hallmark pathological finding is reduced neuromelanin pigmentation in the substantia nigra due to neuronal loss.

choices.text: Gall bladder thickness >3 mm on USG
Preferential visualization of gall bladder in HIDA scan

questions.text: 50-year-old obese female presents to the emergency department with severe right upper quadrant pain, fever, and nausea. The physician suspects acute cholecystitis and orders imaging studies to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following statements is not true about acute cholecystitis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Preferential visualization of gall bladder in HIDA scan.

 

This statement is not true. In a Hepatobiliary Iminodiacetic Acid (HIDA) scan, the gallbladder is not preferentially visualized in acute cholecystitis. Instead, one of the hallmark findings in acute cholecystitis on a HIDA scan is non-visualization of the gallbladder due to inflammation and obstruction of the cystic duct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gall bladder thickness >3 mm on USG: This statement is true and is a common finding in acute cholecystitis. On ultrasound (USG), a thickened gallbladder wall, typically greater than 3 mm, is indicative of inflammation and is a characteristic feature of acute cholecystitis.

 

Option B. Murphy's sign positive: This statement is true. Murphy's sign is a clinical maneuver used to assess for acute cholecystitis. It involves palpation of the right upper quadrant during inspiration, and if the patient experiences pain or stops breathing due to pain during this maneuver, it is considered a positive Murphy's sign, suggesting inflammation of the gallbladder.

 

Option C. Leukocytosis: This statement is true. Acute cholecystitis is associated with an inflammatory response, leading to an elevation in white blood cell count, which is known as leukocytosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute cholecystitis is a common condition characterized by inflammation of the gallbladder, typically due to the presence of gallstones obstructing the cystic duct. Clinical features of acute cholecystitis include right upper quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis. A positive Murphy's sign is right upper quadrant tenderness on palpation. On ultrasound imaging, gall bladder thickness >3 mm is a common finding in acute cholecystitis. The HIDA scan is a diagnostic tool for acute cholecystitis, showing non-visualization of the gall bladder 3 hours after radioisotope administration. Preferential visualization of the gall bladder on a HIDA scan is not a feature of acute cholecystitis. It is important to diagnose and treat acute cholecystitis promptly to prevent complications such as gallbladder perforation or gangrene.

questions.text: Which hormone is most affected by changes in sex hormone binding globulin (SHBG) levels?  (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: A. Testosterone

 

Explanation:

 

Testosterone levels are significantly influenced by changes in sex hormone binding globulin (SHBG). SHBG has a higher affinity for testosterone compared to estrogen, making it more susceptible to fluctuations in SHBG levels. When SHBG levels increase, more testosterone is bound and less is available in its free, bioactive form. Conversely, when SHBG levels decrease, more testosterone is available in its free form. This binding dynamic is crucial because only free testosterone can activate androgen receptors and exert biological effects.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option B (Estrogen) is incorrect because, although SHBG also binds to estrogen, its affinity for testosterone is higher, thus affecting testosterone levels more profoundly.
  • Option C (Progesterone) is incorrect as SHBG has a lower affinity for progesterone than for testosterone.
  • Option D (DHEA) is incorrect because DHEA (dehydroepiandrosterone) is primarily bound by albumin rather than SHBG, and thus is less influenced by changes in SHBG levels compared to testosterone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The level of free, biologically active testosterone in the blood is more significantly affected by changes in SHBG levels compared to other sex hormones due to its higher binding affinity.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presented to the outpatient department with gum bleeding and fever for the past 2 months. General examination showed pallor and the systemic examination was unremarkable. Laboratory examination revealed Hb level- 3 gm/dI, TLC-1500/microL, platelet count - 15000/microL. Peripheral smear shows macrocytes and the reticulocyte count is 0.5. Bone marrow examination revealed fatty streaks and absent megakaryocytes but no immature cells. What is the likely diagnosis? (Hb- Hemoglobin, TLC- Total leucocyte count)? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia

 

The given clinical scenario showing a young male with gum bleeding, fever, pancytopenia, and a low reticulocyte count with bone marrow showing fatty streaks and no immature cells is suggestive of idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia.

 

Key Diagnostic Features of Aplastic Anemia:

 

  • Pancytopenia (low Hb, WBC, and platelets)
  • Hypocellular (fatty) bone marrow
  • No immature/blast cells
  • Low reticulocyte count (indicates bone marrow failure)
  • Macrocytes due to ineffective hematopoiesis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH): PNH is characterized by hemolysis, hemoglobinuria (especially in the morning), and thrombosis. The presentation of pancytopenia with bone marrow aplasia is more suggestive of idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia.

 

Option C. Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS): MDS are a diverse group of hematopoietic clonal stem cell disorders characterized by abnormal development of various marrow elements (i.e., dysmyelopoiesis), cytopenias, cellular marrow, and ineffective blood cell formation.

 

Option D. Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis can cause pancytopenia if the bone marrow is involved, but the bone marrow would show granulomas rather than the fatty streaks and absence of immature cells seen in aplastic anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Causes of pancytopenia

 

I. Aplastic anemia

 

II. Pancytopenia with normal or increased marrow cellularity

 

e.g.

 

  1.  Myelodysplastic syndromes
  2. Hypersplenism
  3.  Megaloblastic anemia

 

III. Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria

 

IV. Bone marrow infiltrations

 

e.g:

 

  1. Hematologic malignancies (leukemias, lymphomas, myeloma)
  2. Non-hematologic metastatic malignancies
  3. Storage diseases
  4. Osteopetrosis
  5. Myelofibrosis

questions.text: A stool sample is collected. The specimen is processed for examination and is labeled at different levels as A, B, C, and D. Identify the level at which parasitic ova will be seen when viewed under a microscope? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) D

 

The above image shows formal ether sedimentation technique.

 

Sedimentation techniques use solutions of lower specific gravity than the parasitic organisms, thus concentrating the latter in the sediment. It takes advantage of the high specific gravity of protozoan cysts and helminth eggs compared to water. Their natural tendency to settle out in aqueous solutions can be accelerated by light centrifugation.

 

Formalin fixes the eggs, larvae, oocysts, and spores, so that they are no longer infectious, as well as preserves their morphology. Fecal debris is extracted into the ethyl acetate phase of the solution. Parasitic elements are sedimented at the bottom.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. A: This level contains ether, which is used to extract fecal debris and is found at the top of the tube after centrifugation.

 

Option B. B: This level contains the plug of debris, which is a layer of waste material that is separated from the parasitic elements and sits below the ether layer.

 

Option C. C: This level contains formalin, which fixes and preserves the morphology of the parasitic elements. The formalin layer sits above the sediment but below the plug of debris.

 

Educational Objective

 

In the formal ether sedimentation technique, parasitic ova, cysts, and larvae will be concentrated in the sediment at the bottom of the tube, labeled as level D. This sediment is where parasitic elements are found and examined under a microscope.

questions.text: You are participating in a research discussion about the best approach to study the circadian changes in the fat content of expressed breast milk among mothers of preterm babies. The primary aim is to observe the variations over time and establish a temporal relationship. Which of the following study designs would be most suitable to achieve this objective? [AIIMS MAY 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Prospective Cohort

 

  • The study design of choice for the given scenario is a prospective study.
  • In the given situation, the study cohort would comprise of mothers with preterm infants, whereas the control cohort would include mothers with full-term babies.
  • To investigate the diurnal fluctuations in the fat composition of expressed breast milk, samples of breast milk would be collected at designated time points each day.
  • These samples would be monitored over the course of multiple days and subjected to analysis. This research constitutes a prospective study.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ambispective Cohort: An Ambispective cohort includes both retrospective and prospective cohort study. This case scenario will not fit in retrospective study

 

Option C. Case control: Case-control study is also a retrospective study.

 

Option D. Cross sectional: Cross-sectional study is used to figure out the prevalence of a disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A prospective cohort study is the optimal design for research that needs to observe how a variable changes over time and establish a chronological sequence of events or effects. This method will allow for the systematic collection of breast milk samples at various times to analyze changes in fat content relative to the time of day in a defined sample of mothers with preterm infants.

questions.text: You are a public health researcher evaluating a new screening test for early detection of a specific disease in a community. Your team successfully conducted a pilot study in a small group. Before planning a large-scale implementation, you wish to ensure that the findings from your pilot study can be applied to larger, diverse groups of individuals outside your initial sample. This ability to extrapolate the findings in the broader population, i.e. the external validity of a screening test is related to which of the following options? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Generalizability

 

  • Generalizability refers to the extent to which the findings from a study or pilot test can be applied to a broader population.
  • It is a measure of the external validity of a study.
  • Ensuring that the results of a pilot study can be extrapolated to larger, diverse groups outside the initial sample is crucial for the success of large-scale implementations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stability: Refers to the consistency of test results over time, ensuring that repeated measurements yield the same results under unchanged conditions. While important, it does not address how findings apply to different populations.

 

Option B. Objectivity: Ensures that test results are unbiased and not influenced by the person administering the test. While critical for reliable results, it does not relate to applying findings to a broader population.

 

Option D. Repeatability: Refers to the consistency of the test results when repeated under identical conditions. This is crucial for reliability but does not address the applicability of the results to different populations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

External validity of a screening test is related to generalizability.

 

Validity refers to what extent the test measures which it purports to measure (adequacy of measurement).

 

Types of Validity

choices.text: Observe the patient for 2 hours post meal
Ask the psychiatrist to prescribe anti-anxiety medication
Increase the calories from 1500 to 2000 in her diet

questions.text: A patient of anorexia nervosa was eating all her meals according to the prescribed diet chart but there is no change in her weight after 1 week. Which of the following needs to be done? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Observe the patient for 2 hours post meal

 

A lack of weight gain in an anorexia nervosa patient adhering to a diet can suggest surreptitious purging behaviors:

 

Observe the patient for 2 hours post meal: This helps in ensuring the patient isn't purging post-meal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anti-anxiety medication: Anxiety is common in anorexia but doesn't directly address potential purging.

 

Option C. Increase calories: Confirm proper consumption and retention before adjusting calories.

 

Option D. Increase water intake: This won't address the primary concern and may introduce other issues.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In patients with anorexia nervosa who are not gaining weight despite adherence to a meal plan, it's important to first rule out surreptitious purging behaviors. Observing the patient post-meal can help ensure that they are not engaging in behaviors like vomiting or excessive exercise after eating.

 

Reference: Shorter Oxford Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 320.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of dizziness, difficulty swallowing, and slurred speech. He also reports numbness on the right side of his face and difficulty feeling hot or cold on the left side of his body. On examination, he has ipsilateral ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis consistent with Horner's syndrome on the right side. There is loss of pain and temperature sensation on the right side of the face and on the left side of the body. He also has gait ataxia and difficulty with coordination. Which area is most likely affected by the lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Lateral medulla

 

Explanation:

 

The patient's symptoms are consistent with Lateral Medullary Syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome. This syndrome is typically caused by an occlusion of the vertebral artery or the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), leading to damage in the lateral medulla. The involvement of the trigeminal nerve nucleus causes ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the face, while damage to cranial nerves IX, X, and XI results in dysphagia and dysarthria. The sympathetic chain involvement leads to Horner's syndrome, and the inferior cerebellar peduncle damage results in gait ataxia and vertigo.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral pons

Lesions in the lateral pons often present with facial weakness, loss of sensation, and hearing deficits due to involvement of the facial, trigeminal, and auditory nerves. However, it does not typically present with the combination of ipsilateral Horner's syndrome and contralateral body symptoms seen in lateral medullary syndrome.

 

Option C. Cerebellum

Cerebellar lesions primarily cause coordination and balance issues, such as ataxia and vertigo. However, they do not produce the specific sensory deficits or cranial nerve abnormalities observed in this case, particularly the crossed pattern of symptoms characteristic of lateral medullary syndrome.

 

Option D. Thalamus

Thalamic lesions can result in sensory deficits involving the entire body on the contralateral side due to its role in sensory relay. However, thalamic strokes do not present with the cranial nerve symptoms, Horner’s syndrome, or the specific crossed sensory findings characteristic of lateral medullary syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lateral medullary syndrome, most commonly caused by vertebral artery or PICA occlusion, presents with a combination of ipsilateral facial sensory loss, Horner’s syndrome, contralateral body sensory loss, and cerebellar symptoms. Recognizing this distinct pattern helps localize the lesion to the lateral medulla and differentiates it from other brainstem and cerebellar syndromes.

questions.text: The correct order of steps in Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is: (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Denaturation, Annealing, Extension

 

Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is a widely used method to amplify specific DNA segments. The process involves three main steps that are repeated in cycles, resulting in the exponential amplification of the target DNA sequence.

 

Steps of PCR:

 

 

The steps of 1, 2 and 3 are repeated results in the exponential amplification of DNA segments of defined length. In each cycle, the DNA strands are doubled. Thus 20 cycles provide for 1 million times amplifications. These cycles are generally repeated by automated instrument, called Thermal cycler.

 

After the amplification procedure, DNA hybridization technique or Southern blot analysis with a suitable probe, shows the presence of the DNA in the sample tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of steps in Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is Denaturation, Annealing, and Extension. These steps are repeated in cycles to exponentially amplify the target DNA segment.

questions.text: A 6-foot 5-inch man undergoing a routine physical examination was found to have an early diastolic murmur. His family pedigree chart is given below. Identify the mode of inheritance of this condition: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Autosomal dominant

 

Notice that the disease is present in all 3 generations. It is being transmitted with equal frequency from affected father to his daughters and son. So, it is autosomal dominant mode of inheritance.  The patient's height and the presence of early diastolic murmur in the given clinical scenario are suggestive of Marfan syndrome

 

Marfan syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects connective tissue, including the skeleton, cardiovascular system, and eyes.

 

Important features of Marfan syndrome:

 

  • Tall stature with disproportionately long limbs and fingers (arachnodactyly)
  • Aortic root dilation, which can lead to aortic aneurysm and dissection
  • Mitral valve prolapses
  • Lens dislocation, which can cause visual impairment or blindness
  • Skeletal abnormalities, such as scoliosis and chest deformities
  • Stretch marks (striae) on the skin that are not related to weight gain or loss
  • Joint hypermobility
  • Autosomal dominant inheritance

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of Marfan syndrome is made based on clinical features and genetic testing. Treatment typically involves management of cardiovascular complications, such as regular monitoring of the aorta and prophylactic aortic surgery, if necessary, as well as management of other symptoms such as lens dislocation and skeletal abnormalities.

questions.text: A woman with Grave's disease was taking antithyroid medication throughout her pregnancy. The baby was born with aplasia cutis congenita. Which drug could have caused this condition? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carbimazole

 

Carbimazole is a medication used to treat hyperthyroidism and is known to cause teratogenic effects if used during pregnancy. It can lead to a rare congenital condition called aplasia cutis congenita, where the baby is born with localized areas of missing skin. The use of carbimazole, especially during the first trimester of pregnancy, is linked with this embryopathy, which highlights the importance of careful medication selection in pregnant women with thyroid disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methylthiouracil: Although it is an antithyroid drug, it is less commonly used and not specifically associated with aplasia cutis congenita.

 

Option C. Levothyroxine: This is a thyroid hormone replacement and is used to treat hypothyroidism, not associated with congenital defects.

 

Option D. Hydrouracil: This option appears to be a distractor as no such common drug name exists that is relevant in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MMZ, Carbimazole associated with embryonopathy in first trimester

 

Graves in Pregnancy:

 

<16 weeks: PTU (MM teratogenic)

 

>16 weeks: MMI (PTU hepatotoxicity)

 

Lactation: MMI (RAIA avoided 4-6 weeks after cessation of breastfeeding as RAI is concentrated in breast tissue)

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Hyperthyroidism/Graves/Chap 384

choices.text: Fever > 38.3°C (101°F) on multiple occasions
Duration of fever for more than 3 weeks
Uncertain diagnosis after thorough evaluation

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with intermittent fever. Despite multiple evaluations, including detailed history, physical examinations, and routine laboratory tests, no clear diagnosis has been established. Which of the following criteria is not included in the definition of Pyrexia of Unknown Origin (PUO)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Uncertain diagnosis after thorough evaluation

 

Explanation:

 

The definition of Pyrexia of Unknown Origin (PUO) includes fever greater than 38.3°C (101°F) occurring on at least two occasions, persisting for more than three weeks, and occurring in patients who are not immunocompromised. The diagnosis requires that a comprehensive history, physical examination, and routine investigations do not establish a cause. While "uncertain diagnosis after thorough evaluation" describes the clinical challenge, it is not explicitly listed as part of the criteria, but rather is a consequence of the failure to identify the cause through initial investigations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Fever > 38.3°C (101°F) on multiple occasions: This is an essential component of PUO, helping to confirm the presence of persistent fever that warrants further investigation beyond common febrile illnesses.

 

Option B) Duration of fever for more than 3 weeks: This criterion distinguishes PUO from short-term febrile illnesses, emphasizing the need for an extended investigation when a fever persists without a clear cause.

 

Option C) Immunocompromised state: Immunocompromised individuals are specifically excluded from the PUO definition due to their unique diagnostic considerations and increased susceptibility to infections, which require a separate approach.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The definition of Pyrexia of Unknown Origin (PUO) requires persistent fever over 38.3°C (101°F) lasting longer than three weeks in non-immunocompromised patients, where no clear cause is identified after standard evaluation. Recognizing these specific criteria helps differentiate PUO from other febrile conditions and guide further investigation.
